questions.text: The true statement regarding central chemoreceptors is?

options.label: A
options.text: Detects H+ in brain interstitial fluid

options.label: C
options.text: Located above the surface of the ventrolateral medulla

questions.correct_answer: A. Detects H+ in brain interstitial fluid
questions.explanation:
Details

Location

Bilaterally below (Option C ruled out) the surface of the ventrolateral medulla, immediately caudal to the pontomedullary junction.

Synonyms

  • Medullary chemoreceptors.
  • Chemosensitive areas.

Mechanism of Stimulation

Arterial PCO2 increases

↓

H+ ions in the brain interstitial fluid increases.

↓

Central chemoreceptors get stimulated to increase respiration (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the J receptor reflex except?

options.label: A
options.text: They are located near the pulmonary capillaries.

options.label: B
options.text: Activation of J receptors causes rapid breathing.

options.label: C
options.text: They are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs.

options.label: D
options.text: They are exclusively involved in regulating airway smooth muscle tone.

questions.correct_answer: D. They are exclusively involved in regulating airway smooth muscle tone.
questions.explanation:
Reflex

Stimulus

Receptor

Afferent

Effect

J-receptor reflex
  • Pulmonary edema.
  • Pulmonary congestion.

Juxtapulmonary receptors

Unmyelinated vagal C fibres
  • Rapid breathing.
  • Bradycardia.
  • Hypotension.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is undergoing a respiratory assessment in the clinic. The patient is asked to take a deep breath and hold it for an extended period. During this maneuver, the clinician observes that the patient’s inspiratory phase extends rather than transitioning to expiration. Which reflex is most likely responsible for this observation?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Receptors

Rapidly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors (RARs)

Response

Brief burst of action potentials in response to lung inflation

Feedback Mechanism

Enhances inspiration, especially during vagus nerve recovery

Clinical Significance

Initiates first breath in newborns, generates augmented breaths, prevents lung collapse

Implications

Relevant for respiratory physiology, neonatal resuscitation, and respiratory control mechanisms

questions.text: Which of the following is the receptor for Herring-Breur reflexes?
questions.explanation:
Reflex

Receptors

Stimulus

Afferent

Effect

Inflation Reflex

Slowly adapting stretch receptors

Lung stretching (inhalation)

Large myelinated nerve fibres
  • Inhibits inspiration.
  • ↑ Inspiration duration.

Deflation Reflex

Stretch receptors

Lung deflation

Large myelinated nerve fibres
  • Inhibits expiration.
  • ↓ Expiration duration.

questions.text: What happens if a person inhales a gas mixture containing 5% carbon dioxide (CO2) during voluntary hyperventilation?

options.label: A
options.text: The person will experience a significant drop in arterial PCO 2 , leading to apnea.

options.label: B
options.text: The person will maintain a normal arterial PCO₂ and prevent respiratory alkalosis.

options.label: C
options.text: The person will experience increased alveolar and arterial PCO 2 , preventing apnea.

options.label: D
options.text: The person will experience decreased ventilation due to the stimulation of medullary chemoreceptors.

questions.correct_answer: C. The person will experience increased alveolar and arterial PCO 2 , preventing apnea.
questions.explanation:
Physiological Change

Description

Increase in Alveolar CO₂
  • Inhalation of 5% CO₂ increases the alveoli's partial pressure of CO₂ (PCO₂).
  • Elevated alveolar PCO₂ leads to an increase in arterial PCO₂.

Stimulation of Ventilation
  • A rise in arterial PCO₂ stimulates the medullary chemoreceptors.
  • This results in an increase in ventilation (hyperventilation continues) to eliminate excess CO₂.

Avoidance of Apnea
  • Without additional CO₂, hyperventilation-induced hypocapnia can lead to apnea (temporary cessation of breathing).
  • Inhaling 5% CO₂ prevents a significant drop in arterial PCO₂, avoiding apnea.

Maintaining Blood pH
  • Inhaled CO₂ helps maintain blood pH closer to normal by preventing respiratory alkalosis.
  • This balance is crucial to avoid adverse effects on cellular and enzymatic functions.

New Equilibrium
  • A new equilibrium is established with slightly elevated alveolar and arterial PCO₂.
  • The person continues to hyperventilate as long as CO₂ is inhaled.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does the sensitivity of chemoreceptors decrease?
questions.explanation:
Consequence

Description

Complications

Dyspnea

Difficulty breathing due to impaired chemoreceptor function

Occurs even with non-critically abnormal blood gas levels

Acidosis and Mental Status Changes

Respiratory acidosis from inadequate CO₂ expulsion

Mental status changes, need for ventilatory support

Ventilation-
Perfusion Mismatch

Mismatch due to structural lung changes reduced compensatory mechanism

Complicates breathing regulation

questions.text: Arrange the following in the correct sequence regarding the mechanism of activation of a glomus cell: Depolarisation Calcium influx Reduced K+ conductance Increased ventilation Dopamine release
Decreased arterial blood pressure leads to?
questions.explanation:
Peripheral Chemoreceptors

Central Chemoreceptors

Pathway

Decreased arterial pressure → decreased perfusion of peripheral tissues, including the carotid and aortic bodies → hypoxia (decreased oxygen levels) → stimulation of peripheral chemoreceptors.

Decreased arterial pressure → reduced removal of carbon dioxide (CO2) → CO2 retention → increased arterial PCO2 → increased concentration of hydrogen ions (H+) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) due to the conversion of CO2 to HCO3- and H+ → stimulation of central chemoreceptors in the medulla.

Result

The peripheral chemoreceptors send signals to the respiratory centres in the brainstem to increase the rate and depth of breathing to improve oxygen delivery and restore homeostasis.

The central chemoreceptors also stimulate the respiratory centres to enhance ventilation, thereby increasing the elimination of CO2 and improving blood gas levels.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient, Mr Kumar, is admitted to the hospital with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation. He appears short of breath and has a low oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals: pH: 7.32 PaCO 2 : 55 mm Hg PaO 2 : 55 mm Hg HCO3-: 24 mmol/L What will most likely activate Mr. Kumar's peripheral chemoreceptors?
questions.explanation:
Topic

Details

Location
  • Carotid bodies: At bifurcations of common carotid arteries
  • Aortic bodies: Along the ascending aorta and arch of the aorta

Function

Send signals to the dorsal respiratory group (DRG) in the medulla to increase ventilation

Carotid Bodies

Type I (glomus) cells and Type II (sustentacular) cells

Type I Cells (Glomus Cells)

Release dopamine in response to hypoxia, triggering an action potential in the carotid sinus nerve

Aortic Bodies

Contain glomus cells similar to carotid bodies but are less effective in regulating respiration

Responses
  • Hypoxia: Increased firing rate of afferent nerves when PaO2 < 60 mm Hg
  • Hypercapnia: Linear increase in chemoreceptor discharge rate with increased PaCO2
  • Acidosis: Stimulates ventilation independently of hypoxia and hypercapnia

questions.text: Where is the pneumotaxic centre, which regulates respiratory rate, located in the brain?
The apneustic centre is inhibited by?
Which group of neurons is involved in controlling forceful expiration?
questions.correct_answer: B. Ventral respiratory group of neurons

questions.text: What is the structure responsible for the voluntary control of respiration?

A 45-year-old male was involved in a severe motor vehicle accident resulting in multiple injuries, including a traumatic brain injury. Imaging studies revealed a complete transection of the brain stem below the medulla. Given this anatomical disruption, what would be the most likely effect on the patient's respiratory activity?
questions.explanation:
Level of transection

Vagus intact

Vagus cut

A

Complete transection above the pons

Regular breathing continues

Regular breathing continues; the depth of inspiration increases.

B

Mid-pontine level section

Apneusis

C

Transection midway between the pons and the medulla

Irregular and rhythmic respiration

D

Complete transection below the medulla

Cessation of spontaneous respiration

questions.text: Ondine's curse, or Ondine's syndrome, is a rare disorder of the respiratory control centre. Which of the following is true about Ondine's curse?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of voluntary, but intact automatic control

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of automatic, but intact voluntary control

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of both automatic and voluntary control

questions.correct_answer: B. Loss of automatic, but intact voluntary control

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the primary pacemaker for respiration in the brainstem?
questions.explanation:
Zones

Location

Function

Pre-Bötzinger Complex

Ventrolateral medulla

A primary pacemaker for respiration that generates the basic rhythmic pattern of breathing.

Bötzinger Complex

(Option B ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, dorsal

Modulates respiratory rhythm; involved in expiratory phase regulation and inhibition of inspiration.

Rostral Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

(Option A ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, rostral

It contributes to rhythm generation and integrates respiratory signals; it is involved in the inspiratory and expiratory phases.

Caudal Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

(Option D ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, caudal

Primarily involved in controlling the expiratory phase of respiration.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the functions of the dorsal respiratory group (DRG) of neurons in the medulla? The DRG primarily regulates the rhythmic pattern of breathing. The DRG receives sensory input from peripheral chemoreceptors and baroreceptors. The DRG mainly influences the expiratory phase of respiration. The DRG integrates information from the vagus nerve to adjust breathing depth. The DRG controls voluntary breathing movements during speech.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Dorsal Respiratory Group (DRG)

Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

Location

Medulla oblongata, primarily in the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS)

Medulla oblongata, ventrolateral region, including nucleus ambiguus and nucleus retroambiguus

Primary Function

Controls basic rhythmic breathing; initiates and regulates respiration

Modulates rhythm and force of breathing; involved in complex breathing patterns

Breathing Pattern

Generates and maintains rhythmic breathing; primarily active during inspiration

Modifies breathing patterns; active during both inspiration and expiration

Connection with Other Centers

Integrates sensory input from peripheral chemoreceptors and baroreceptors to adjust breathing

Coordinates with pneumotaxic and apneustic centres; adjust breathing for varying demands

Sensory Input

Receives input from lung stretch receptors and chemoreceptors detecting CO₂ and O₂ levels and integrates information from the vagus nerve to adjust breathing depth

Receives input from higher brain centres

Effect on Breathing

Establishes and regulates basic breathing rhythm; adjusts rate and depth

Fine-tune breathing patterns and force; adjust breathing during different activities

questions.text: Which of the following controls the depth of breathing?
